div.p: Greetings. The envoys complain about your, brother and co-father, importunity; for they send letters both from you and from Solothurn. They ask that I bring you back with words and reprimand you.

But if the matter has been conducted as you write, and I do not doubt that it is so, there is no reason for me to reproach you, as I would have done the same here in a similar case. But I will await the outcome of the matter; the situation is very displeasing.

Indeed, I cannot write more now; for the business of the whole day has exhausted me, and a headache is worsening towards evening. Take these things in good part; otherwise, if the Lord wills, I will write more.
Farewell with the honorable councilors and Philipp and Pontasella, etc. January 13, 1559.
I pray that you faithfully ensure this letter is delivered to Mr. Friedrich von Salis.
To the most excellent man, Mr. Johannes Fabricius, faithful minister of the Church of Chur, his dearest lord and brother. Chur.
